Second take the {@background Sage} background. Third choose the cantrips {@spell Fire Bolt} and {@spell Prestidigitation}. Fourth add two monster links to your research journal, one combining {@spell Burning Hands} and {@spell Grease}, the other combining {@spell Sleep} and {@spell Witch Bolt}.

default: a set of bracelets and anklets for spellcasting
(a) a {@item costume clothes|phb|costume} or (b) {@filter light armor|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=light armor}
(a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) an {@item entertainer's pack|phb}

fluff.name: Dancer
entries: The light of the room dims, and the spotlights focus on the lightly dressed woman who makes her way across the stage. With a large smile, she moves effortless along with the music, filling everyone's hearts with joy and pushing them to stay determined in whatever challenges they have.
Amid the chaos of the battlefield a maiden expertly slides in and out of combat, soothing her allies' wounds and empowering their wills to continue fighting.

Dressed in fine clothing with their trusty blade at their side, the seemingly sweet woman dances through a group of would-be assailants behind her establishment, cutting them down with ease wielding her signature scimitar.

Dancers have harnessed magics and arts, combining them into a spectacle which turns the battlefield into a show, and it is by their graceful movements which their allies are guided to a happy conclusion.

entries.name: Of Silk and Steel
entries: Dancers draw from many different sources and backgrounds, combining them into a single package which covers a wide variety of situations. Using small weapons to pick away at their unwitting foes as their dances debilitate their marks while filling their allies with power. Though a rarity on the battlefield few forget the sight of a skilled dancer at work.

entries.name: Ornaments of Power
entries: Dancers perform their magical feats not through a stave or rod, but rather specially made jewelry worn on the wrists and ankles. As they dance around the battlefield they move their bodies in specific patterns to manipulate the magical power within their bodies and to gather residiual magic in the environment. Once they've gathered the required magic they must keep moving to keep their spell active, channeling the magic further.

entries.name: Creating a Dancer
entries: Dancers are passionate people dedicated to their craft. Spending years practicing has gifted them with the ability to weave spells and their passions together into a gorgeous display of skill. When creating a Dancer, you must consider where they honed their craft. Did they pick up the profession naturally, teaching themselves over long hours, or did they study beneath some kind of mentor? One must consider their motivations, does your Dancer seek fame and fortune, or do they want to bring the gifts of joy to the masses. Perhaps they are going on their journey in an attempt to hone their craft even further.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Dancer quickly by following these suggestions. First make Dexterity your highest abiltiy score, followed by Charisma. Second, take the {@background Entertainer} background.

default: (a) a {@filter martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} and a {@item shield|phb} or (b) two {@filter martial weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon}
(a) a {@item shortbow|phb} and {@item arrows (20)|phb|20 arrows} or (b) two {@item dagger|phb|daggers}
(a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb}

fluff.name: Dark Knight
entries: An Auri man dives into the front line of his foes. Recklessly, he swings his blade with great might, cleaving through foe after foe. The enemy scatters, claiming they battled a demon that day.
A downtrodden woman stands behind an ebony clad Hyur. Despite seeming to be on his last legs his exhaustion leads him to pull greater strength to protect the weak against those who had been pursuing.

A Lalafellin woman stands before a strange demon, clad in dark heavy armour and cloth, she weaves shadow magics before to unleash dark magics to put an end to the demon and silently protect the nearby village from its wrath.

It is a dark knight's freedom from the bounds of the law which make these dark avengers so effective. Unconcerned with what is lawful a dark knight is concerned with what is ethical in their view. Those who spread tyranny and injustice best prepare for a visit from a dark knight who aims to set things right and break the chains of oppressors.

entries.name: Protecting the Meek
entries: A Dark Knight is a knight who has taken up arms to serve the downtrodden. They serve no lords or institutions, believing no one is exempt from justice, no matter what their position in society. They protect the commonfolk from not only banditry and wild beasts, but from corrupt men who seek to oppress them. In return, Dark Knights are often fed and housed by those they protect, or rely upon bounty hunting and raiding looters to support themselves.

entries.name: Internal Darkness
entries: When an adventurer chooses the path of a Dark Knight they understand that they are renouncing their rights to be a regular member of society. They belong to no society, acting as paragons of justice who see no allegiance. To assist them in their quest, Dark Knights are able to sacrifice their own life force to power a well of darkness within themselves. They cause themselves great pain and exhaustion in order to allow dark power to course through their body which they harness in a variety of ways.

entries.name: Creating a Dark Knight
entries: Dark Knights are natural adventurers, living outside the law to see their goals to fruition. They may live within a remote village protecting the inhabitants from bandits, while the land's knights turn a blind eye to their plight, or they may travel the world seeking out institutionalized injustice and smiting it with violence. Dark Knights act on behalf of the common folk, and do so not expecting praise nor admiration. They are aware that they will not be celebrated in the history books like Paladins would be. Instead they expect to be demonized by history and happily accept this fact. One seeking to become a Dark Knight must be introduced to it through some means, be it an ancient tome with their rituals recorded or a mentor to impart their knowledge.

default: (a) a {@filter martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} or (b) two {@item spear|phb|spears}
(a) a {@item shortbow|phb} with 20 {@item arrow|phb|arrows} or (b) two {@item handaxe|phb|handaxes}
(a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb}

fluff.name: Dragoon
entries: An Elezen man stands before a fierce dragon, it roars out and begins to take off in order to gain the advantage. With a massive leap the man lands atop the dragon and forces it back to the ground, creating an opening for his allies.

A Hyur cloaked in scale mail whirls their spear around a cluster of enemies keeping them at bay. When the time is right they unleash a plume of fiery breath from beneath their helm, singing their targets.
A Viera woman runs and leaps high into the sky, magical wings forming on her body. With grace, she travels the currents of the wind, happily flying about as she exercises her new found freedom.

These fearless warriors stand against dragons, demons, fiends and any other threats who would raise a hand against their homelands. Dragoons use their command of both the sky and ground to strike down their foes with deadly strikes.

entries.name: Dragonbane
entries: The Dragoon was a soldier born out of need in a distant land. Their homeland has been locked in a war against dragonkind for hundreds of years, leading to their soldiers to specialize in battling back against dragons. Their most notable ability is the Dragoon Jump, which is powered by a magical gem each Dragoon receives upon completing their basic training.

entries.name: Masters of the Sky
entries: The Dragoons have been blessed with the ability to soar high into the air like those they have taken up arms to destroy. These warriors are able to crash down from the sky using their weapons and body weight to drive any skyborn into the ground, or cause great damage to those already on land. Wings will not grant you safety from a Dragoon.

entries.name: Creating a Dragoon
entries: When creating a Dragoon, consider what brought them down the path of a specialized knight. They may have shown a certain aptitude which allowed them to become a dragoon with ease, or perhaps were born into the role due to the history of their homeland. A dragoon may have decided upon this path due to the stories of famed dragoons of legends, hoping to become as powerful and respected as the knights they had heard about while they were growing up. You must consider as well how the Dragoon came to possess the blessed gem in their possession granting them their jumping prowess.

Consider why a Dragoon would choose to head out on an adventure. Are they seeking a specific dragon, hoping to slay an enemy of their nation? Could your dragoon have unfinished business with a dragon from their past? Sometimes a dragoon may set out for the sake of journeying around the land.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Dragoon quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Strength your highest ability score,following with Dexterity. Second take the {@background Soldier} background

default: a {@filter martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} which has already been converted to a gun blade.
(a) a {@item shield|phb} or (b) a {@item pistol|DMG} and 20 {@item Renaissance Bullet|DMG|bullets}
(a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|PHB}

fluff.name: Gunbreaker
entries: Dusty and worn down, a man wielding a large two handed blade plunges it into a formidable beast standing before him. He pulls the trigger on the handle of the blade and sends a shockwave through the creature, stunning it for his allies to capitalize.

A woman lunges forward with her Gunblade in hand, as she cuts across her foes body she pulls the trigger unleashing flaming energy from her blade, making quick work of her enemy. She flashes a wild smile to the allies of her quickly defeated foe and beckons they try their luck against her sword arm as well.

Carefully, a man lines up his fire arm to take a shot at his approaching foes. He pulls the trigger and a blast of thundrous energy launches from his blade, crashing into the approach enemy, causing him to drop with a thud.
The Gunbreakers are innovative warriors who take the field with their trusty Gunblades in hand. Able to handle a variety of combat situations, the Gunbreaker exhibits a mastery over the battlefield.

entries.name: Art of War
entries: There were once great generals so skilled at warfare that their work could have been seen as artistic. War forces mankind to innovate, and as such lead to the inception of the Gunbreaker. This unique creation features a a melee weapon infused with triggers and munitions to augment their attacks greatly. Despite being known alternatively as Gunblades their weaponry most tend to use focus melee combat, battling on the front lines.

entries.name: A Symbol for Rebellion
entries: The Gunbreakers find their roots in conflict. Desperate resistance fighters of Dalmasca, forced underground by the invading empire devised new and powerful arms to fight back against their oppressors, causing the Gunbreaker to shine as a rally call to rise up against anyone who'd crush others under their foot.

entries.name: Creating a Gunbreaker
entries: When creating a Gunbreaker, one must consider how they came to design their powerful weapon. It may have been a group effort, or one born from desperation. Perhaps the wielder of the gun blade sought only to experiment with weaponry and discover new ways to deliver destruction to their foes.

You must also consider why the Gunbreaker has decided to head off on their journey. Perhaps they stand for those who cannot stand for themselves, with dreams of ridding their home of evil forces. They may be a gritty mercenary who has found a efficient ways of dealing with problems, and a client who has many problems to see to. Perhaps they are testing the new weapon outside of their smithy it was forged in. It could be as simple as wanting to see the world or be a part of something bigger than themselves.
Whatever the reason, the Gunbreaker is a powerful ally to have on your side and fearful foe to face down.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Gunbreaker quickly by following these suggestions. First make Strength your highest ability score, following with Dexterity. Second take the {@background Folk Hero} background.

tools: two sets of artisan's tools of your choice

default: (a) an {@item explorer's pack|PHB} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|PHB}
(a) a set of {@filter artisan's tools|items|type=artisan's tools} of your choosing

fluff.name: Machinist
entries: A woman stands before a group of goblins. Negotiations have broken down and the goblins have drawn their blades. Before they can take a step towards her, she unleashes a lethal bullet from her pistol, laying their leader low, causing the others to retreat in fear of this unknown weaponry.

Carefully, an exhausted machinist puts the finishing touches on their newest creation. They flip the switch and the small tower shaped machine takes flight. It receives its commands and a tiny pistol lets loose a bullet destroying the target. A smile spreads across the master tinkerer's face.
A man wearing leather armor approaches a horde of invaders who'd overrun their home given the chance. They toss a mechanical sphere into the group and in an instant they're enshrouded in flame.

Machinists have spent many hours in the workshop to progress the art of war. From the creation of firearms, to the production of mechanical constructs for the battle field, the machinist ensure the gears of war continue to turn ever efficiently.

entries.name: Forefront of Innovation
entries: A Machinist is an incredibly skilled artisan who has decided to push the boundaries of current technology and has managed to do so successfully. They are capabable of building a wide variety of machines and firearms which they use to overwhelm enemies of their homes through sheer efficiency. Those who welcome a Machinist to live within their city will be granted the boons of a true genius.

entries.name: In the Name of Advancement
entries: The first step of a Machinist's path is developing an aetherconverter. This device draws the latent magic energy within the Machinist out and uses it to power their devices. Due to their aetherconverter powering their devices, there are few in the world who are able to use them. For that reason, it falls upon the Machinist themself to head out into the world to field test their creations. The Machinist must push their creations to their limit and continue to modify them. As adventurers this is the drive of a machinist, to test their equipment and rework it on a long journey in the name of science and innovation.

entries.name: Creating a Machinist
entries: When creating a machinist you must keep in mind why they may be heading out on their adventure. Is your machinist field testing their inventions, or seeking inspiration to create even more intricate machines? Perhaps they are on a journey to make the world a better place by bestowing their creations for the common man. A Machinist has the most advanced technology at their finger tips and are using that technology to make life more efficient.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Machinist quickly by following these suggestions. First make Dexterity your highest ability score, following with Intelligence. Second take the {@background Guild Artisan} background.

tools: two sets of {@item artisan's tools|PHB} of your choice.

default: (a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|PHB}

fluff.name: Red Mage
entries: Like a lightning bolt streaking through the battlefield, she makes quick work of foe after foe. At the first sign of danger, the crimson beauty flips over the head of the foe behind her, letting loose a wave of energy as a parting gift.
A confident smirk spreads across the face of the veteran red mage. He unleashes spell after spell in quick succession, drawing on countless elements until his foe is annihilated.

As though a flower amonst a sea of weeds, the red mage leads their allies into battle. With a deep trust that they'll stay at their side, she turns her friends into the perfect dancing partners for this adventure, empowering them to match their grace.

Red Mages have drawn on a multitude of disciplines across the world, mixing black and white magic along with focused swordplay and style. All of these abilities have combined in this alluring mix of talent and flair, creating a hero worthy of becoming legendary.

entries.name: Crimson Mage
entries: Some fairy tales of Gyr Abania speak of the heroic deeds and daring adventures of mages clothed in crimson. These adventurers are known as Red Mages, and travel the world protecting the good in the world by drawing on both white and black magic, while mixing martial prowess into a flawless battle style.

entries.name: It's Not About Fame
entries: Their thirst for adventure, flashy style and renowned flair may lead many to believe that a Red Mage becomes an adventurer for the admiration of their fellow men, but that is not the case. Those who take the Red do so in order to take up arms to protect the good in the world and bring wrongdoers to justice. It is their heroic spirit which drives them to action, the garnered fame is just a perk.

entries.name: Creating a Red Mage
entries: When creating a Red Mage, you must consider why they may be heading out on their adventure. Did they become fed up with the oppressive nature of the world and seek the need to become a hero to the common man? They may have learned of a plot which endangers their home, perhaps the world as a whole and will stop at nothing to end it. Maybe it is simply a need to chase the thrill of adventure and become a hero of legend.

One key consideration to make as a Red Mage is where you came to learn your myriad of skills. Was it through the study of old tomes you discovered in an abandoned warehouse or library? Did you meet a mentor who saw great potential in you and introduced you to the art? Whatever the origin, you wield powerful skills with an artistic flair.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Red Mage quickly by following these suggestions. First make Charisma your highest ability score, followed by Dexterity. Second take the {@background Folk Hero|PHB} background Third take the {@spell fire bolt}, {@spell jolt|FFXIV}, {@spell mage hand} and {@spell prestidigitation} cantrips, and the first level spells {@spell chromatic orb} and {@spell cure wounds}.

default: (a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack}
a decorative scabbard for your katana

fluff.name: Samurai
entries: The young man stands before a ferocious beast, his blade still sheathed the villagers look on in horror as it closes in on its prey. With a smirk the man draws his blade and in a few lightning quick strokes, the beast falls with a thud.

The experienced veteran stands before a group of bandits. Their untrained strikes are easily dodged by the man, as he delivers blow after blow viciously, punishing each of their failed attempts on his life.

A young woman wanders into the city, her identity hidden beneath her shade. She hears of the oppression of the people in the village by the local lord. She nods to herself, knowing she has arrived at yet another town which would be better off without a master.

Far across the churning waves, beneath the rising sun, an island nation gave birth to a prolific style of swordplay. These noble warriors were sworn to their masters as their protectors, willing to give up their lives to see their duty complete. Honour or death was a common ideal for these disciplined soldiers.

entries.name: Swordsmen of Legend
entries: The Samurai are legendary swordsmen who lived by a code of honour. In service to the lords of their regions, they protected their lands with their lives and enforced their law without question. To do so, the Samurai nourished a timeless style of swordplay which remains mythic in its reputation to this day.

entries.name: The Power Within
entries: The Samurai draw on inner energies and an unshakeable discipline. These are the tools which the Samurai built their reputation. To take up and master the katana is to enter a league of your own, though not every samurai has been known to wield the blade for a master, some choosing to follow their own code and travel the world.

entries.name: Creating a Samurai
entries: When creating a Samurai, you have to decide how they became involved in the discipline. Were they born into the tradition, being the son of a samurai or lord? Perhaps they fight in a self-taught style which they continually hone through their travels.

On top of their roots as a samurai, you must consider why you fight as a samurai. Are you on a quest on behalf of a lord, or directly protecting their master's lands. Perhaps they cast off their ties to their masters and teachers altogether and travel the world for their own gain, or the protection of the common man.

entries.name: Creating a Samurai
entries: You can make a Samurai quickly by following these suggestions. First make Strength your highest ability score, following with Wisdom. Second take the {@background Soldier} background.

default: (a) a {@item shortbow|PHB} and {@item arrow|PHB|20 arrows} or (b) two {@item handaxe|phb|handaxes}
(a) an {@item explorer's pack|PHB} or (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb}
{@item chain mail|phb} and a carved wooden idol related to your heritage

fluff.name: Warrior
entries: A Roegadyn woman stands locked in combat with a hobgoblin. With each swing of his blade, she meets with ferocity and powerful blows. The battle rages on, the woman feeding off the ecstasy of battle, receiving succor with each blow she lands.
A man dashes into the heat of battle, his battleax swinging wildly around him. He lets out an earth shaking battle cry as he crushes the ground and all those around him with explosive force.

A lightly armored figure stands at his ally's sides. His powerful voice echoes out across the field, empowering his allies as he leads his comrades into battle, axe drawn and swinging like a tempest of steel and iron.

entries.name: Indomitable Forces
entries: The warrior finds their roots in ancient tribes akin to barbarians. These fearless fighters are peerless in their control of a force which they call the inner beast. Warriors often come from tribal backgrounds in which they learn to nurture and control this inner animal, which in turn grants them beast like strength and ferocity. Warrior bands once roamed unsettled lands as nomads, enjoying the boons which nature offers and defending the weak from those who would do them harm.

entries.name: Unending Rage
entries: Not unlike nature itself, a Warrior has the potential to become a relentless force of destruction. Like a raging forest fire, or an all consuming tidal wave, a warrior can unleash their inner beast to harness its rage. This state of being is known as berserking. While berserking, Warriors continually • chase foes and defend allies, using their bloodlust to keep themselves in the battle as a threat.

entries.name: Creating a Warrior
entries: When creating a Warrior, one must consider their origins as a warrior. Are you a descendant of the ancient tribes from which warriors are able to draw their lineage? Perhaps you were a fledgeling adventurer who found a mentor in the form of a former warrior who passed on the secrets of the inner beast. Perhaps you had a natural attunement to the ways of the warrior and have developed your skills without guidance.

You must also consider why you have set out on your life of adventuring? As a warrior, have you decided to seek out dangerous challenges to sharpen your skills or sate the appetite of the hungry beast inside you? Perhaps you have taken up arms in defense of your tribe, a village or a loved one? Warriors set out for any number of reasons.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Warrior quickly by following these suggestions. First make Strength your highest ability score, following with Constitution. Second take the {@background Outlander} background.

default: a spellcasting focus (a cane, staff, wand or similar object)
(a) an {@item explorer's pack|phb} or (b) a {@item scholar's pack|phb}

subclasses.name: Spirit Master
subclassFeatures: Touch of the Padjal|White Mage|FFXIV|Spirit Master|FFXIV|14

fluff.name: White Mage
entries: A quiet and well groomed man waves his cane around himself, drawing in magical energy from the land and calling forth it's power. With a flick of his wrist the land parted and erupted sending his foe toppling to the ground.
A gentle young woman rushes to their ally's side. Through prayer and reverence for the land, it's power is shared with her, allowing her to close the wounds of her dying friend.
A stern heavily robed figure approached the abomination, raised from the dead. Calling for shining light, she banishes the undead back to the abyss.

Serene and elegant, the White Mages commune with the world around them, borrowing power from elementals present throughout the word. They are level headed, respectful spell casters who are aware that overstepping one's bounds in the world of magic can lead to calamity, and seek to keep order within the magic world while mending the wounds of those around them.

entries.name: One with the Land
entries: White Mage's strength stems from an art they refer to as conjury. Conjury calls upon the elements of earth, wind, and water and concentrates them to a potency at which spells can be weaved. Through practiced meditation on the essences of creation, conjurers draw forth and absorb magic from their immediate surroundings. A wand or cane made from unworked wood is then utilized to focus the magical energy until it manifests as the desired spell Versed also in magicks that restore and strengthen, White Mages are regarded as accomplished healers.

entries.name: Patrons of Light
entries: White Mages find their roots in a society which revered nature as an ally, borrowing the power of the land and elementals to soothe wounds and protect from the wicked. Over time, the White Mages of the past overused this power causing the elementals to act out and smite the land, alongside the damage wrought by the opposing Black Mages, the world fell into a dark age. Today White Mages are few and far between, practicing the forbidden art to wield the powers of nature and light to drive off evil in protection of the world again.

entries.name: Creating a White Mage
entries: When creating a White Mage one must question how they came into the art of conjury and the profession of White Mage. Did a kindly mentor take you under their wing? Did your studies of magic from the past lead you to discovering how to draw power from the world you lived in? Perhaps the elementals which inhabit the land reached out to you and their whispers guided you to the path of a White Mage. Nonetheless a White Mage's role in the world is that of a protector, soothing the wounds of those who need it most, settling enraged elementals and driving the beings who bring destruction back from whence they came.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a White Mage quickly by following these suggestions. First make Wisdom your highest ability score, following with Charisma. Second select the Healer discipline. Third take the {@background Acolyte} background. Fourth, take the {@spell Guidance}, {@spell Light}, {@spell Sacred Flame}, and {@spell Spare the Dying} cantrips and the first level spells {@spell Cure Wounds} and {@spell Heroism}.

default: (a) a {@filter martial weapon|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=martial weapon} or (b) two {@filter simple weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon}
(a) a {@item light crossbow|phb} and {@item crossbow bolts (20)|phb|20 bolts} or (b) {@item hand crossbow|phb} and {@item crossbow bolts (20)|phb|20 bolts}
(a) {@item studded leather armor|phb} or (b) {@item scale mail armor|phb}

subclasses.name: Order of the Ghostslayer
subclassFeatures: Blood Curse of the Exorcist|Blood Hunter|BH2020|Ghostslayer|BH2020|15

subclasses.name: Order of the Profane Soul
subclassFeatures: Order of the Profane Soul|Blood Hunter|BH2020|Profane Soul|BH2020|3
Brand of the Sapping Scar|Blood Hunter|BH2020|Profane Soul|BH2020|11
Blood Curse of the Souleater|Blood Hunter|BH2020|Profane Soul|BH2020|18

entries: Marred but resolute, his grimacing face dripping with sweat, a half-orc reddens a finger across his wounds to draw a glowing, ruby glyph in the air. He grips the weightless, completed sigil, twisting it to unleash dark magical energies that fire forward, cursing the stalking behemoth from within its own veins to better even the odds.

A mysterious half-elf swathed in a worn cloak and rugged leather armor carefully investigates a grizzly scene off the roadway, her eyes flashing with recognition as she meditates on the remnants of the massacre.The survivor who warily hired her with draws with a jump as the half-elf suddenly shoots to her feet, sure in the knowledge of the culprit, where it calls home, and how little time there is to find it.

Stepping into the lightless chambers of ancient dust and lingering whispers, the halfling's nose picks up the pungent smell of imminent danger as she hears the scraping of bone and claw on nearby stone. She winces as she runs her blade across her palm, the steel transmuting her blood into glowing runes of powerful magic, her sword suddenly engulfed in arcane flames, eager to brand and burn the flesh of her enemies.

Often feared or misunderstood, and driven by an unending drive to destroy the wicked, blood hunters are clever, arcane warriors who have bound their essence to the dark creatures they hunt to better stalk and survive their prey. Armed with the rites of forbidden blood magic and a willingness to sacrifice their own vitality and humanity for the cause, they protect the realms from the shadows, ever vigilant to avoid becoming the same monsters they choose to hunt.

entries.name: Sacrifice to Preserve Life
entries: While most of the classic schools of magical study are well known and widely respected, the less refined and macabre incantations of Hemocraft have long been forbidden and lost to most of the civilized world. Blood Hunters have reclaimed these techniques away from the judging eyes of society, finding blood magic's esoteric nature effective against the evils that often defy the divine powers that historically hold the line.

Through careful study and practice, blood hunters have honed the rites of hemocraft into their combat prowess, forfeiting a facet of their health to infuse their weapons with powerful blood magic and summoning the elements to envelop their strikes.

They can sear an arcane brand into the body of their quarry that hinders their foe's abilities and punishes their aggression, or call blood curses upon their enemies, manipulating their bodies from the inside. Willing to suffer whatever it takes to achieve victory, these adept warriors have forged themselves into a potent force against the terrors that threaten the innocent.

entries.name: A Monster to Fight Monsters
entries: Whether driven by the wish to make a difference in a dangerous world, the need to take vengeance for a great wrong they have suffered, being inspired by witnessing the strange and powerful techniques of another blood hunter in person, or just seeking a place to belong in an uncaring world, the reasons one may take up the Hunter's Bane and choose this life are many and varied. In joining an order of blood hunters, one is also joining a tight family bound by service to each other and the common cause. For many, this is the only family they have known or have left, so the kinship felt between members of an order is a bond neigh unbreakable.

Beyond the boundaries of the order, however, the life of a blood hunter is often not an easy one. The rituals of the Hunter's Bane regularly leave one visibly changed and prone to unsettle common folk, and the witnessing of hemocraft can invoke a superstitious fear from even the most learned scholar. While some societies have come to accept the good deeds of the orders, many blood hunters publicly hide their nature unless absolutely necessary, feeling more comfortable in the wilds and wastes of the world where the Orders commonly train. Even so, the best work a blood hunter can do usually involves the poor and defenseless on the outskirts of society, those prone to the corrupting touch of fiends and dark intension. Braving the threat of vilification, these dark protectors wade through civilization, earning coin as mercenaries or bounty hunters, ever watching for the signs of something more nefarious beneath the surface.

In choosing this path, a blood hunter has irrevocably given a part of themselves to their cause, physically, emotionally, and sometimes morally. The orders of blood hunters practice their own unique ideals and methods, often employing techniques with dark origins that test the strength and will of these guardians. Many wrestle with the fear of losing this struggle, so a life of discipline and vigilance drives their travels as they wander the country side in search of like-minded adventurers and whispers of dark deeds afoot.

entries.name: Creating a Blood Hunter
entries: As you create a blood hunter, the most important aspects of your character are why you were driven to this lifestyle, and why do you seek to give up everything to wallow in the dark with the evils you hunt? Did you lose a loved one to a fiendish beast and now wish to prevent others from suffering the same fate? Do you seek a sense of purpose and security, and found this among the order that has taken you in? Have you always carried a seed of darkness within you, and seek kin to watch over you and prevent you succumbing to it? Were you once a holy warrior who strayed from his faith and was cast out, but still seek to give yourself to the cause of protecting the innocent? Or are you a criminal with a dark past seeking to make amends, taking this life as a path of penance?

What is your relationship with the powers of hemocraft and the abilities it promises to grant you as you step closer to its mastery? Do you respect and fear the ancient power that surges through your veins, using them only when necessary? Do you relish in the strength it offers you, embracing your gifts and using them freely? Are you worried the superstitions are right, and this power will eventually turn you into one of the monsters you hunt? Or has your study instilled you with the confident control of mind over matter, certain you can bend these gifts to bring a brighter dawn?

Consider too that while a blood hunter belongs to an order, many strike out on their own to do their best work. What made you leave the comfort of your order? Do you intend to return, or have you decided you have more to learn in the world beyond? What do you seek in other adventurers that can help you meet your goals?

While most blood hunters follow a path of good or neutrality in their pursuits, some have fallen to the dark, seductive side of hemo craft and use their abilities for selfish and evil purposes. These deviants are always thrown from the order, and often hunted along with the creatures they once trained to fell.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a blood hunter quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Strength or Dexterity your highest ability score, depending on whether you want to focus on melee weapons, or archery (or finesse weapons). Make Intelligence your next highest if you plan to focus on the potency of blood curses and mystical power. Choose a higher Constitution next, as you want to have extra hit points to burn on your crimson rite or amplifying blood curses. Then, select the {@background urchin} or {@background soldier} background.

entries.name: Blood Hunter Multiclassing
entries: Should you wish to multiclass into a blood hunter, the prerequisites and proficiencies gained are listed below.

entries.name: Ability Score Minimum
entries: Strength 13 or Dexterity 13, and Intelligence 13

entries.name: Proficiencies Gained
entries: Light armor, medium armor, shields, simple weapons, martial weapons, alchemical supplies.

entries.name: Proficiencies Gained
entries: If multiclassing Order of the Profane Soul with Warlock levels, add a third of your blood hunter levels (rounded down) to your Warlock level and consult the Warlock progression table in the Player's Hand book for total Spell Slots, Cantrips known, and Spell Slot Level.

fluff.name: Blood Hunter

default: (a) a longsword OR (b) any martial weapon
(a) an Explorer’s Pack OR (b) a Dungeoneer’s Pack
(a) an Arcane Focus OR (b) any simple weapon

classFeatures.name: Draconian Origins
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you have draconic blood running through your veins as part of your draconic inheritance. You gain the following benefits:
You learn how to speak, read, and write draconic. If you already have draconic from another source, you can choose one other language.

Choose either chromatic or metallic, then choose from either black, blue, green, red, or white for chromatic. Brass, bronze, copper, gold, or silver for metallic. These determine your draconic origin, what type of dragon is responsible for your powers, and what type of scales riddle your body.
Depending on your choice, you gain resistance to a specific damage type.
If you chose metallic, you gain proficiency in your choice of either an artisan’s tool or a musical instrument.
If you chose chromatic, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills: deception, intimidation, performance, or persuasion.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Body
entries: Your body is riddled with dragon-like scales, granting you natural armor. While you are not wearing armor your AC equals 13 + your constitution modifier. You can still gain the benefits of a shield.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Powers
entries: Also at 2nd level you learn the ancient secrets of dragons. You know how they can fly, shoot fire - lighting - acid - even frost out of their mouths. You start off with 2 Draconian Powers and gain more as shown in the Dragon Warrior table. Some Draconian Powers are locked away by prerequisites that must be met before they obtain any of these sacred powers such as level and Draconian Origins. You can exchange a Draconian Power for others every time you level up.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 3rd level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at 5th level, when you take the attack action on your turn you can make an additional weapon attack.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 6th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 18th level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 20th level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

subclassFeatures.name: Summoner
entries: Draconic blood flowing through your veins may not be enough. Sometimes, you need an extra set of hands, or claws rather. In addition to draconic blood, you have a dragon’s soul intertwined with yours. Realizing the hidden power within your soul, you can call upon that soul and magically create a companion that is a manifestation of the draconic soul within you.

subclassFeatures.name: Manifest Dragon
entries: Starting at 3rd level, as an action you can manifest a magical dragon to aid you in battle. Use the “Magen Dragon” stat block. In addition to being a construct, the creature is also treated as a dragon. The manifested dragon shares its initiative with you and it can move, but it cannot use any of its actions on its own. You can command it as a bonus action, allowing it to use one of its actions. This command can be either mentally given, or verbally. Being a construct, the dragon cannot receive healing from any sources unless it can otherwise affect constructs.

The manifested dragon uses your proficiency bonus rather than its own and its armor class is 13 plus its constitution. Each time you manifest the dragon, you either roll its hit point formula or take the average.

Once your manifested dragon is reduced to 0 hit points, it is destroyed and cannot be manifested again until you finish a long rest. Alternatively, during a short you can spend half of your hit dice to manifest your dragon, however its hit points are halved. Once you do so, you cannot do so again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Unleash Draconic Fury
entries: Also at 3rd level, when you take the attack action while your dragon is manifested, your dragon can make an additional melee attack against a creature within 5 ft of it. You have a number of uses of this feature equal to your Charisma Modifier, and regain all expended uses after a short rest or long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Greater Manifestation
entries: At 7th level, your manifested dragon has now become stronger and is a more viable asset. The dragon can freely act on its own and no longer requires to be commanded to use one of its actions. Its size increases to large and can speak, read, and write common and draconic. If you spend 8 hours training your dragon, it can learn an additional language, but only if you know the language yourself.
It can now attack twice using any combination of its bite, claws, or tail, but can only bite once. Its breath weapon’s damage increases by 2d6 and the range of its cone increases by 15 ft.
Its hit dice increases from a d6 to a d8 and each of its ability scores increases by 2. It also gains 2 additional hit dice.
Its walking speed increases by 10 ft and its flying speed increases by 20 ft.

subclassFeatures.name: Shared Mind of the Drakes
entries: At 10th level, you can now link with your manifested dragon’s senses. You can temporarily transfer your consciousness to your manifested dragon. As an action, you can see through your dragon's eyes and hear through its ears. During this time, you are deafened and blinded. You can sustain this effect for up to 10 minutes, and you can end it at any time (requires no action).
If you or your dragon takes damage, you must make a concentration check as if you were concentrating on a spell. If you fail, this effect ends and your senses are returned to normal.

subclassFeatures.name: Superior Manifestation
entries: At 14th level, your manifested dragon has reached its adulthood and is now a fierce foe in combat. Its size becomes huge and each of its attacks deals an additional damage die. Its bite attack also deals an additional 2d10 damage corresponding to its breath weapon.
It can now attack three times using any combination of its bite, claws, or tail, but can only bite once. Its breath weapon’s damage increases by 2d6 and the range of its cone increases by 30 ft.
Its hit dice increases from a d8 to a d10 and each of its ability scores increases by 3. It also gains 3 additional hit dice.
Its walking speed increases by 10 ft and its flying speed increases by 20 ft.

subclassFeatures.name: Mournful Sacrifice
entries: At 18th level, if you were to die by any means while your dragon is manifested, you can instantly destroy your manifestation and expend all remaining uses of your Manifest Dragon feature to avoid dying. When you do so, you are brought to your feet at 1 hit point instead.
Sacrificing your dragon in this way leaves a scar on your magical ability to manifest it.

The first time your manifested dragon is destroyed in this manner, you cannot summon it again under any circumstance for 7 days. Each time afterward increases the amount of time by an additional 7 days, up until after the third time you’ve done so. In which case, if it is destroyed in this way again, you cannot summon it again by any means. Only a wish spell can restore your ability to manifest your dragon, upon which you can use this feature once before you lose the ability to manifest it again under the same means.

subclassFeatures.name: Supreme Manifestation
entries: At 20th level, your dragon has reached its peak potential and is now your most powerful ally. Its size becomes gargantuan and deals twice as much damage to structures and objects. Each of its attacks deals an additional damage die, and its extra damage for its bite becomes 3d10 instead of 2d10.
It can make four attacks using any combination of its bite, claws, and tail but can only bite once. Its breath weapon’s damage increases by 4d6 and the range of its cone increases by 30 ft.
Its hit dice increases from a d10 to a d12 and each of its ability scores increases by 4. It also gains 4 additional hit dice.
You can manifest your dragon twice before completing a long rest instead of once, but you can only have one dragon manifested at a time.

subclassFeatures.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you have discovered an ancient heritage of magical prowess and have gained the ability to cast spells. See chapter 10 for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the sorcerer spell list.

subclassFeatures.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you have discovered an ancient heritage of magical prowess and have gained the ability to cast spells. See chapter 10 for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the sorcerer spell list.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. You learn an additional sorcerer cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries:
The Invoker Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your sorcerer spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell shield and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast shield using either slot.

Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher. You know three 1st-level sorcerer spells of your choice.
The Spells Known column of the Invoker Spellcasting table shows when you learn more sorcerer spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be an abjuration or evocation spell of your choice, and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the sorcerer spells you know with another spell of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries:
Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, since you learn your spells through supernatural powers. You use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a sorcerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier

subclassFeatures.name: Invoke Energy
entries: At 3rd level, you have a pool of Invoke Energy equal to your Dragon Warrior level, you regain spent invoke energy after a long rest. You learn two invocations that you can spend invoke energy and a bonus action to use them:

entries.name: Draconic Arms
entries: By spending 1 invoke energy, you morph your arms and hands into dragon-like appendages. You gain a natural weapon in the form of claws. These claws use strength for your attack and damage rolls and deal 2d6 slashing damage on hit. You can make an attack using these claws as part of this bonus action. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, after which your appendages return to normal.

entries.name: Draconic Legs
entries: By spending 1 invoke energy, you morph your legs and feet into dragon-like appendages. Your movement speed increases by 10 ft and you can take the dash action as a bonus action. You can take the dash action as part of this bonus action. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, after which your appendages return to normal.

subclassFeatures.name: Additional Invocations
entries: At 7th level you can choose one of the following invocations to learn, you learn another invocation at 15th and 20th levels:

entries.name: Draconic Build
entries: As an action, you can spend 2 invoke energy to morph your torso into a more draconic-like one. The scales you have become more defined and you become more durable. Your armor class increases by 2 and you gain 10 temporary hit points. If you are hit with a melee attack while you have these temporary hit points, the attacker takes 10 points of damage. This damage is correspondent to the damage you resist from your Draconic Origins. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, or until you lose these temporary hit points, after which your torso returns to normal. You can spend an additional 2 invoke energy to increase the temporary hit points and damage by 10, but the duration of the invocation is halved.

entries.name: Draconic Eyes
entries: As a bonus action, you can spend 2 invoke energy to morph your head into a dragon’s head. During which time your darkvision is increased by 60 ft and you gain a blindsight of 10 ft. You can also see into the ethereal plane and see invisible creatures and objects. They appear as if they were ethereal outlines. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, after which your head returns to normal. You can spend an additional 2 invoke energy to double the range of this increase, but the duration of the invocation is halved.

entries.name: Dragonfire
entries: As a bonus action you can spend 2 invoke energy, dragonfire erupts from a weapon you choose. That weapon deals an additional 1d6 damage, this damage corresponds to the damage you resist from your Draconic Origins. This invocation lasts for 1 minute, or until you end it as a bonus action. You can make a single weapon attack as part of this bonus action. You can spend 2 additional invoke energy to boost the dragonfire’s damage by an additional d6, but the duration of the invocation is halved.

subclassFeatures.name: Invoke Element
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you roll acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage, you can spend 1 Invoke Energy to replace that damage type with a different type from the same list.

subclassFeatures.name: Adept Invocations
entries: At 14th level, whenever you would spend invoke energy to boost an invocation, you can choose not to spend the extra energy and still gain the boost. You can do so a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier and regain spent uses after a long rest.

subclassFeatures.name: Invoke Arcane
entries: At 18th level, you add your spellcasting ability modifier to the damage of your spells. In addition, you can spend any number of invoke energy to re-roll the same number of damage dice for a spell that deals damage. You must use the new result, even if it is lower than the original.

subclassFeatures.name: Invoke Control
entries: At 20th level, when you roll initiative with no invoke energy, you regain 5. In addition, when you finish a short rest you replenish half of your invoke energy.
Also, whenever you use your action or bonus action to spend invoke energy, you can immediately cast a spell with the same casting time as the action you used. You can only do so once per round.

subclassFeatures.name: Runic Scribe
entries: With the ancient power of draconic runes, these dragon warriors tattoo themselves with unwieldy magic. They learn these ancient runes as they grow stronger and are passed on to them from the knowledge of their ancestors. Awaken the truths behind your draconic origins and learn the ancient ways.

subclassFeatures.name: Runic Tattoos
entries: Starting at 3rd level, magic runes appear on your person. These runes represent an ancient dialect of old draconic. If it is relevant for your campaign, you learn of the oldest form of draconic, predating the one currently being used. These runes hold significant power represented by long forgotten old magicks. Choose one of the following runes:

entries.name: Rune of Power
entries: You’ve harnessed the power of the old magicks and can release outward a blast of arcane energy. You learn the Eldritch Blast cantrip and can cast it using Charisma as your spellcasting ability modifier. You also add your spellcasting ability modifier to the damage of this cantrip. Instead of green eldritch energy, the beam takes the form of wispy dragon-like flames more akin to a dragon’s breath weapon.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of untapped power. Your charisma score increases by 2 to a maximum of 22. Any time after you cast the Eldritch Blast cantrip while the boon is invoked, each beam deals an additional 1d10 damage. This boon lasts for 1 hour, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again for 7 days.

entries.name: Rune of Knowledge
entries: You’ve gained a rune that grants you knowledge of the ancient world. During a short rest, you can spend 10 minutes meditating, reminiscing of the past. When you do so, you can learn of old techniques used for modern items. You gain proficiency in one tool or skill of your choosing. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses this tool or skill. You lose proficiency in this skill if you use this feature again, or when you complete a long rest.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of untapped knowledge. Your Intelligence score increases by 2 to a maximum of 22. While the boon is invoked, each time you roll an ability check that doesn’t add your proficiency bonus using Intelligence, you add half of your proficiency bonus to that check. This boon lasts for 1 hour, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again for 7 days.

entries.name: Rune of Draconic Weaponry
entries: Instead of being scribed on your person, you can scribe this rune onto a weapon of your choosing. That weapon becomes enhanced by the rune’s ancient magic, allowing it to take a more draconic-like appearance riddled with scales.

The weapon becomes magical for the purposes of overcoming non-magical resistances if it wasn’t magical already. In addition to the weapon’s normal damage, it also gains a bonus 1d6 damage corresponding to the damage type you resist from your Draconic Origins. This bonus damage increases to 1d8 at level 5, 1d10 at level 11, and 1d12 at level 17. You can only have one weapon inscribed with this rune’s magic at a time.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of untapped strength. Your strength score increases by 2 to a maximum of 22. You have advantage on all weapon attacks made with a weapon etched with this rune. This boon lasts for 1 hour, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again for 7 days.

subclassFeatures.name: Advanced Runic Power
entries: Starting at 7th level, you’ve begun to delve more into your runic arts, learning more and more of the ancient ways. Choose one of the following runes to learn:

entries.name: Rune of Recovery
entries: You’ve etched a tattoo of old magicks capable of mending wounds. As an action you touch a creature, they regain 1d10 + your Charisma modifier hit points and are cured from one disease or poison afflicting them. You have two uses of this rune, regaining all spent uses after a short or long rest.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of health. Your Constitution score is increased by 2, to a maximum of 22. While the rune is invoked, you are immune to poison and disease and you restore 1 hit point at the start of each of your turns. This boon lasts for 1 hour, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again for 7 days.

entries.name: Rune of Blustering Winds
entries: A magic tattoo appears on your back, resembling runes in the shape of dragon-like wings. Whenever you take the dash action, you do not provoke opportunity attacks and you ignore the effects of difficult terrain. As a reaction, whenever a ranged weapon attack would hit you, you can impose disadvantage on that attack, potentially causing it to miss as you summon forth a powerful gale from the palm of your hands.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of immense speed enough to lift you off your feet. Your Dexterity score is increased by 2, to a maximum of 22. While the rune is invoked, you have a flying speed of 30 ft and you can hover. If you already have a flying speed, it is increased by 30 ft. This boon lasts for 1 hour, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again for 7 days.

entries.name: Rune of Foresight
entries: A rune appears over your forehead, representing a third eye, as a bonus action you can take a defensive stance on your turn so long as you have not moved more than half of your movement speed. While in this defensive stance, you reduce any incoming damage by half as you pivot away from the full force of it. This has no effect on spells or magical effects that fully envelops your space, nor does it reduce psychic damage.

As an action, you can invoke a more latent power of the rune, granting you a boon of true foresight. Your Wisdom score is increased by 2, to a maximum of 22. While the rune is invoked, you have advantage on Wisdom (Insight) checks and as a reaction if you were to be hit by a weapon attack, you can instead choose to avoid the attack entirely. This boon lasts for 1 hour, after which you cannot invoke the power of this rune again for 7 days.

subclassFeatures.name: Runic Warrior
entries: Starting at 10th level, your attunement to your runes has given you an unnatural resistance against magical effects. You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects. In addition, spell attacks have disadvantage against you if you are within 15 ft of the caster.

subclassFeatures.name: Runic Replenishment
entries: At 14th level by spending half of your hit dice during a short rest, you can replenish the usage of invoking latent power for one of your runes. Once you do so, you cannot do so again for that rune for 7 days.

subclassFeatures.name: Additional Runes
entries: At 18th level, choose any two rune options from 3rd or 7th level. Both runes do not have to be from the same list of runes.

subclassFeatures.name: Runic Mastery
entries: At 20th level, after a long rest you can replenish the usage of invoking one of your runes latent power. In addition, the maximum ability score the latent power of your runes can increase becomes 24 instead of 22.

A Dragon Warrior is a powerful fighter who has either made a deal with a dragon, has been blessed by a dragon, has killed a dragon or was around when a dragon died and absorbed its power, or was raised by a dragon. Either way, a Dragon Warrior uses the magical power that originated from a dragon, but has evolved it into their own power. While Dragons are indeed magical they are very limited on the spell casting end of things, which is what the Dragon Warrior tries to make up for with physical combat. One of the many benefits of the Dragon Warrior is that they have a lot of options, there are a lot of options that the Dragon Warrior can have and many that they will never obtain. There is a lot of versatility and choices for each Dragon Warrior, making 1 entirely different from the others. If you like a class with a lot of options, then this may be one for you.
fluff.name: Dragon Warrior

default: (a) a Quarterstaff OR (b) any simple Weapon
(a) an Explorer’s Pack OR (b) a Priest’s Pack
A memento of your draconic heritage

classFeatures.name: Draconian Origins
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you have draconic blood running through your veins as part of your draconic inheritance. You gain the following benefits:
You learn how to speak, read, and write draconic. If you already have draconic from another source, you can choose one other language.

Choose either chromatic or metallic, then choose from either black, blue, green, red, or white for chromatic. Brass, bronze, copper, gold, or silver for metallic. These determine your draconic origin, what type of dragon is responsible for your powers, and what type of scales riddle your body.
Depending on your choice, you gain resistance to a specific damage type.
If you chose metallic, you gain proficiency in your choice of either an artisan’s tool or a musical instrument.
If you chose chromatic, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills: deception, intimidation, performance, or persuasion.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Shape
entries: Harnessing the draconic powers that dwell within you, you can transform your shape to resemble a more draconic figure. As an action you can morph your body into that of a dragon. When you take this form, you become a large creature and your creature type changes from humanoid to dragon. At this level, you are a lesser dragon so you can understand languages, but you cannot speak or cast spells.You retain the benefit of any features from your class, race, or other source and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can't use any of your special senses, such as darkvision, unless your new form also has that sense. You also retain your statistics. Such as armor class, hit points, movement speed, skill proficiencies, etc.
You can choose whether your items being worn or carried morph into your new form, or drop to the ground at your feet.

While in this form, your AC is 13 plus your Wisdom modifier and you have natural weapons in the form of bites and claws. Each of these weapons deals 1d10 plus your strength or dexterity modifier in your choice of slashing or piercing damage. If you have the “Draconian Claws and Fangs” Draconian Power, it replaces this damage. You can also make one attack using your natural weapons as a bonus action.

You can stay in a draconian shape for a number of hours equal to half your dragon shaman level (rounded down). You can revert to your normal form earlier by using a bonus action on your turn. You automatically revert if you fall unconscious, drop to 0 hit points, or die.
You can use this feature once, after which you cannot use it again until you finish a short or long rest. You gain an additional use of this feature at 10th level, and another one at 20th level.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 1st level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

classFeatures.name: Draconian Powers
entries: Also at 2nd level you learn the ancient secrets of dragons. You know how they can fly, shoot fire - lighting - acid - even frost out of their mouths. You start off with 2 Draconian Powers and gain more as shown in the Dragon Shaman table. Some Draconian Powers are locked away by prerequisites that must be met before they obtain any of these sacred powers such as level and Draconian Origins. You can exchange a Draconian Power for others every time you level up.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at 5th level, when you take the attack action on your turn you can make an additional weapon attack.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Roar
entries: Starting at 6th level you can unleash a mighty roar to strike fear into your enemies. As an action while in your Draconian Shape, you can force each creature that can both see and hear you within 60 feet of you to make a Wisdom saving throw DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier. On a failed save, each creature is frightened. On a success, the creature is immune to your roar for the next 24 hours.
Immediately after being frightened in this way, each creature is knocked prone and must use their action to dash away from you. If there is nowhere to run, the creature may take the dodge action.
At the end of each affected creatures’ turns, they can repeat their saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Flight
entries: Starting at 9th level, while in your Draconian Shape, you have a flying speed of 60 ft. In addition, your creature size becomes huge instead large and you can carry up to four creatures without reducing your speed while in your Draconian Shape.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 10th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 11th level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Might
entries: At 13th level you’ve awakened a power from deep within. While in your Draconian Shape, you can choose to gain advantage on your melee attacks, but attacks made against you have advantage.
Your AC in your Draconian Shape becomes 15 plus your Wisdom modifier.
You can make a single attack using one of your natural weapons when you use your Draconian Shape feature.
In addition, while in your Draconian Shape the damage resistance granted from your Draconic Origins becomes a damage immunity instead.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Age
entries: At 15th level, your dragon-like abilities have allowed you a timeless body and an increased lifespan. You suffer none of the frailty of old age, and you can't be aged magically. You can still die of old age, however.
In addition, the draconic magic that you wield causes you to age more slowly. For every 100 years that pass, your body ages only 1 year.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 16th level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

classFeatures.name: Dracronian Master
entries: At 18th level, you can ignore the verbal and somatic components of your spells, as well as any material components that lack a cost and aren't consumed by a spell. You gain this benefit in both your normal shape and your Draconian Shape.
In addition, whenever you roll for initiative when you have no uses of your Draconian Shape, you regain 1 usage.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

classFeatures.name: Draconian Archetype Feature
entries: At 20th level, you gain a feature from your chosen Draconian Archetype

subclassFeatures.name: Path of the Wildling
entries: You were born in the wild, raised by the wilderness and nature itself. Along this path, you have learned that you possess a power to bend and control the nature around you, causing great changes to the terrain around where you call home.

subclassFeatures.name: Terraforming Presence
entries: Starting at 1st level, as an action on your turn, you can cause the area around you to shift and turn, transmogrifying the ground beneath you for 1 minute. You create a 10 ft radius cylinder, centered on you, of difficult terrain. The cylinder moves with you, and you are immune to the effects of this difficult terrain. In addition, you can choose up to a number of creatures equal to your Wisdom modifier to be immune to these effects as well. Depending on the damage you gain resistance to from your Draconic Origins, one of the following effects becomes active, the effects ending when the difficult terrain returns to normal. You have a number of uses of this feature equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all expended uses after a long rest. If your effect requires a saving throw, the DC is 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Fire
entries: Plumes of lava rise from the ground and the ground beneath you becomes volcanic-like in appearance. As a bonus action on your turn, you can make a ranged spell attack using Wisdom as your spellcasting ability against a creature you can see within 60 ft of your difficult terrain. On hit, the target takes 2d6 fire damage and is on fire. At the start of each of the creatures' turns they take 5 points of fire damage. That creature, or another creature within 5 feet, can use an action to smother out the flames, ending the effect.

entries.name: Cold
entries: The ground beneath you freezes solid and becomes icy terrain. As part of the same action the turn you use your Terraforming Presence, and as an action on all subsequent turns thereafter, you can impose a Constitution saving throw against your Draconian Save DC on each creature suffering the effects of your difficult terrain. On a failed save, the creature takes 2d6 cold damage and is incapacitated until the end of your next turn as frost coils around their body, incasing them in ice. On a success, the creature takes no damage and is not incapacitated.

entries.name: Lightning
entries: A heavy lightning storm brews around you. As a bonus action on each of your turns, you can launch a bolt of lightning toward each creature suffering the effects of your difficult terrain. Each creature makes a Dexterity saving throw against your Draconian Save DC. On a failed save, they take 2d6 lightning damage, or half as much on a success. At the start of each of their turns, each creature suffering the effects of your difficult terrain must make a Constitution saving throw against your Draconian Save DC, or be blinded until the end of your next turn on a failed save.

entries.name: Acid
entries: The ground beneath you becomes squishy, soft, and damp. As a bonus action, you can cause the moisture from beneath the ground to rise and lash it out on creatures suffering from your difficult terrain. They make a Dexterity saving throw against your Draconian Save DC, taking 2d6 acid damage on a failed save and their AC decreases by 2 until the end of your next turn, or no damage on a success and does not have their AC reduced.

entries.name: Poison
entries: Earthy plants, brambles, and vines rise from the ground around you. As a bonus action, you can cause plants to sprout and release a noxious gas against creatures suffering from your difficult terrain. They make a Constitution saving throw against your Draconian Save DC, or take 2d6 poison damage and become poisoned on a failed save, or they take no damage and are not poisoned on a success.

subclassFeatures.name: Superior Terraforming
entries: Starting at 6th level, your Terraforming Presence’s range increases by 10 ft., in addition the damage dealt by your difficult terrain effects increases by 1d6.

subclassFeatures.name: Natural Respite
entries: Also at 6th level, when you complete a long rest, you can end the effects of one disease or condition afflicting you. In addition, you regain all expended hit dice at the end of a long rest and gain an amount of temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier. You can only gain these benefits if you complete your long rest outdoors.

subclassFeatures.name: Beastly Shape
entries: Starting at 11th level, you can expend a usage of your Draconian Shape to cast the Polymorph spell without expending a spell slot or requiring material components, but you can only target yourself. Wisdom is your Spellcasting Ability for this spell. In addition to being considered a beast, its creature type also counts as dragon.

subclassFeatures.name: Wild Nature's Release
entries: Starting at 16th level, your connection to nature allows you to push yourself in order to protect it. While  transformed by your Draconian Shape, you can enter a relentless rage to strike down any creature who would dare challenge you in the game “Survival of the Fittest”.

While in your Wild Nature’s Release, you have advantage on all Strength ability checks. In addition, you have resistance to all damage except force, psychic, and necrotic. Also, damage dealt by your natural weapons or your Terraforming Presence gains a bonus equal to your Wisdom Modifier.

Your Wild Nature’s Release ends after 1 minute, if you end it early as a bonus action, if you are incapacitated, if you die, if your Draconian Shape ends, or if you end your turn not hostile toward a creature.

subclassFeatures.name: Warrior of the Beast
entries: Starting at level 20, when you use the Beastly Shape feature you retain your alignment, personality, and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiencies, in addition to gaining those of the creature. If the creature has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the creature's bonus instead of yours.

In addition, your Polymorph form does not require concentration to maintain the form and you can cast spells in your beast form as you retain the most basic ability to speak. You can also remain in your beast form indefinitely, unless you are dropped to 0 hit points or die.

Also, your Polymorph form retains the benefits of any features from your class, race, or other source and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can't use any of your special senses, such as tremorsense, unless your new form also has that sense.

subclassFeatures.name: Path of the Ancients
entries: Your ancestry stems back to ancient times, dragons of old encompass your past, and you can call forth their ancient might to aid you on your journeys. Their knowledge immense, their presence calming, and their friendship irreplaceable.

subclassFeatures.name: Ancestral Ally
entries: Starting at 1st level, as an action, you can spend a usage of your Draconian Shape to instead summon a dragon rather than transform. Use the “Ancestral Ally” stat block for this feature.  In addition to being undead, the creature is also treated as a dragon. The ancestral ally shares its initiative with you, but moves immediately after you do. Being undead, the dragon cannot receive healing from any sources unless it can otherwise affect undead.

The ancestral ally takes the visage of its youngest form to represent the progression of its shaman, it can accurately recall information from its life and is more than willing to share that information, but not for free.

Being dead, the dragon no longer has any desire for material wealth. Instead, the dragon wishes to learn something in return. Make either a Charisma (Persuasion) ability check or an Intelligence ability check of the DM’s choosing.

The base DC is 10, but the DM may increase the DC to a maximum of 25 depending on the information being learned. Things that may increase the difficulty would be extra personal information the dragon may not be as willing to share, or if the information is something the shaman can ordinarily gain themselves.
